user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_linux_probe_bus:
```c
static int metal_linux_probe_bus(struct linux_bus *lbus)
{
	struct linux_driver *ldrv;
	int ret, error = -ENODEV;

	lbus->sbus = sysfs_open_bus(lbus->bus_name);
	if (!lbus->sbus)
		return -ENODEV;

	for_each_linux_driver(lbus, ldrv) {
		ret = metal_linux_probe_driver(lbus, ldrv);
		/* Clear the error if any driver is available */
		if (!ret)
			error = ret;
	}

	if (error) {
		metal_linux_bus_close(&lbus->bus);
		return error;
	}

	error = metal_linux_register_bus(lbus);
	if (error)
		metal_linux_bus_close(&lbus->bus);

	return error;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_linux_probe_bus:
static int metal_linux_probe_driver(struct linux_bus *lbus,
				    struct linux_driver *ldrv)
{
	char command[256];
	int ret;

	ldrv->sdrv = sysfs_open_driver(lbus->bus_name, ldrv->drv_name);

	/* Try probing the module and then open the driver. */
	if (!ldrv->sdrv) {
		ret = snprintf(command, sizeof(command),
			       "modprobe %s > /dev/null 2>&1", ldrv->mod_name);
		if (ret >= (int)sizeof(command))
			return -EOVERFLOW;
		ret = system(command);
		if (ret < 0) {
			metal_log(METAL_LOG_WARNING,
				  "%s: executing system command '%s' failed.\n",
				  __func__, command);
		}
		ldrv->sdrv = sysfs_open_driver(lbus->bus_name, ldrv->drv_name);
	}

	/* Try sudo probing the module and then open the driver. */
	if (!ldrv->sdrv) {
		ret = snprintf(command, sizeof(command),
			       "sudo modprobe %s > /dev/null 2>&1", ldrv->mod_name);
		if (ret >= (int)sizeof(command))
			return -EOVERFLOW;
		ret = system(command);
		if (ret < 0) {
			metal_log(METAL_LOG_WARNING,
				  "%s: executing system command '%s' failed.\n",
				  __func__, command);
		}
		ldrv->sdrv = sysfs_open_driver(lbus->bus_name, ldrv->drv_name);
	}

	/* If all else fails... */
	return ldrv->sdrv ? 0 : -ENODEV;
}
...
static int metal_linux_register_bus(struct linux_bus *lbus)
{
	lbus->bus.name = lbus->bus_name;
	lbus->bus.ops  = metal_linux_bus_ops;
	return metal_bus_register(&lbus->bus);
}
...
static void metal_linux_bus_close(struct metal_bus *bus)
{
	struct linux_bus *lbus = to_linux_bus(bus);
	struct linux_driver *ldrv;

	for_each_linux_driver(lbus, ldrv) {
		if (ldrv->sdrv)
			sysfs_close_driver(ldrv->sdrv);
		ldrv->sdrv = NULL;
	}

	sysfs_close_bus(lbus->sbus);
	lbus->sbus = NULL;
}
...
static struct linux_bus *to_linux_bus(struct metal_bus *bus)
{
	return metal_container_of(bus, struct linux_bus, bus);
}
...
int metal_bus_register(struct metal_bus *bus)
{
	if (!bus || !bus->name || !strlen(bus->name))
		return -EINVAL;
	if (metal_bus_find(bus->name, NULL) == 0)
		return -EEXIST;
	metal_list_init(&bus->devices);
	metal_list_add_tail(&_metal.common.bus_list, &bus->node);
	metal_log(METAL_LOG_DEBUG, "registered %s bus\n", bus->name);
	return 0;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No unreachable code was found in the provided fragments. Control flow is entirely conditional and all statements can be reached depending on runtime conditions: sysfs_open_bus has an early return when it fails (reachable when the bus cannot be opened); the for_each_linux_driver loop body is reachable when drivers exist (and may be skipped if none exist, which is not unreachable code but conditional execution); metal_linux_probe_driver contains two sequential probe attempts where the second is only executed if the first did not succeed (both branches reachable depending on sysfs_open_driver and system() results); the error check after the driver loop leads to metal_linux_bus_close and return when no driver succeeded (reachable when error remains nonzero); metal_linux_register_bus is called only when at least one driver probe succeeded and its error path calls metal_linux_bus_close (both reachable when registration fails). Helper functions (metal_linux_bus_close, to_linux_bus, metal_bus_register) contain early returns or conditional behavior that are reachable given their inputs (e.g., metal_bus_register returns errors for NULL/empty name or existing bus). There are no statements that are syntactically placed after an unconditional return or otherwise provably unreachable across all execution paths in the supplied code, so no fragments require investigation for Rule 2.1.
